message.content:
cs.CV, cs.AI, cs.LG, cs.NE, cs.CL 

This paper is likely to belong to the computer vision (cs.CV) sub-category as it deals with saliency methods for deep neural networks, which are commonly used in computer vision tasks such as image classification and object detection. Additionally, the paper proposes a fix for existing saliency methods that helps them pass sanity checks, which is a common concern in the computer vision community. 

The paper could also belong to the artificial intelligence (cs.AI) and machine learning (cs.LG) sub-categories as it deals with deep neural networks and their interpretability, which are important topics in these fields. 

The neural networks (cs.NE) sub-category is also a possibility as the paper deals with credit-assignment via the gradient of the output with respect to input, which is a common technique in neural network training. 

Finally, the natural language processing (cs.CL) sub-category is a less likely possibility as the paper does not explicitly deal with language processing, but it could be relevant if the proposed method is applied to text-based tasks.
